summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from December 2020 between a U.S. Attorney's Office and defense counsel, primarily scheduling calls. It includes a draft 'statement of facts' regarding an unnamed female assistant ('Jane Doe') who worked for Jeffrey Epstein, detailing her role in scheduling massages for minors, her own victimization, and her alleged actions to dissuade victims from cooperating with law enforcement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the criminal investigation. The document details his sexual abuse of dozens of minor girls during massage appointments scheduled by his assistant.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as directing the unnamed assistant ('Jane Doe') and providing her with a directory of contacts to schedule massages for Epstein.

persons.name: Jane Doe
persons.role: Epstein's personal assistant / alleged victim and facilitator
persons.context: An unnamed female assistant who worked for Epstein from approximately 2001-2013. The document states she was a victim of sexual abuse by Epstein and, as part of her duties, scheduled hundreds of massage appointments for minors during which abuse occurred. She allegedly later tried to dissuade victims from speaking to law enforcement.

connections.description: Jane Doe worked as a personal assistant for Jeffrey Epstein from approximately 2001 to 2013.
The document states the Government does not dispute that Jane Doe was herself a victim of sexual abuse by Epstein.
Maxwell provided Jane Doe with a contact directory and directed her to schedule massage appointments for Epstein.
Maxwell is implicated in directing the assistant's activities related to scheduling appointments for Epstein's abuse.
Multiple minor victims reported to law enforcement that Jane Doe was present for or walked in on instances of their sexual abuse by Epstein.

events.title: Jane Doe's Employment with Epstein
events.description: Jane Doe worked as a personal assistant for Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Scheduling of Massage Appointments for Minors
events.description: During this period, Jane Doe scheduled hundreds of appointments for women and girls, including dozens of minors, to massage Epstein, during which he sexually abused them.

events.title: Jane Doe Learns of Investigation
events.description: Jane Doe learned law enforcement was investigating Epstein for sex crimes involving minors. At Epstein's direction, she called multiple minor victims to encourage them to 'help' Epstein and dissuade them from speaking to law enforcement.

events.title: Victim Interviews by Federal Law Enforcement
events.description: Multiple minor victims were interviewed by federal agents as part of the criminal investigation into Epstein and his associates for sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Draft Statement of Facts Circulated
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sent a draft statement of facts regarding Jane Doe to defense counsel, clarifying it was not a plea offer but reflected recent discussions.

locations: 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: An unnamed female assistant ('Jane Doe') who worked for Jeffrey Epstein from ~2001-2013 was herself a victim of his sexual abuse, according to a government-recognized expert report.
Between 2002-2005, this assistant scheduled hundreds of massage appointments for Epstein, involving dozens of minor victims (ages 14-17), leading to their sexual abuse.
Multiple minor victims reported to law enforcement that this assistant was present for or walked in on instances of their abuse, though she denies participating.

In 2005, after learning of the investigation into Epstein, the assistant, at his direction, called minor victims to discourage them from cooperating with law enforcement, offering legal help and financial incentives.
The document is a 2020 draft statement of facts shared by prosecutors, indicating ongoing plea negotiations or discussions related to this assistant's role and culpability.
